bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., February 7, 1948

div1.p: Hench informs Carter, Jr. that he is writing a book about Henry Rose Carter. Hench explains his procedures in organizing collections of letters and requests Carter, Jr.'s help.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., February 7, 1948
div1.opener:
February 7, 1948
Dr. H. R. Carter, Jr.
1927 First Avenue North
Birmingham, Alabama
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am writing a book on the conquest of yellow fever. I have spent
considerable time collecting the data during the last 7 years, such time as
my practice here at the Mayo Clinic will allow. I have visited Cuba three
times, visited most of the surviving relatives of Reed and his various col-
leagues and had indeed a most delightful experience. I have uncovered a
mass of unpublished data and believe that my book will be the definitive
one on the subject.

One of the parts of the story that is not quite complete is that of
the connection between your father, Doctor Carter, and Walter Reed. I am,
of course, aware of the great influence which your father's papers had on
Lazear and Reed but I have been unable to determine what actual physical
relationship there was between your father and the Army Commission. I have
been unable to find out at what time in their work your father's work was
called to the attention of the Army Board and whether it was called first
to the attention of Lazear or Reed and by whom. In searching for data along
this line, I discussed the matter at the last meeting of the Board of Managers
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, which meets annually in Washington,
and of which I am a new member. Admiral Stitt is an old member of that Board.
He gave me some useful hints and suggested that I get in touch with the rela-
tives of your father. I did not know your address but have had some corres-
pondence with Mr. H. C. Redd of Richmond, Virginia. I understand that there
are three trunks of correspondence of your father. Mr. Redd has, I believe,
made a very brief inventory of the trunks and believes that there may be in
these letters much of medico-historical value. He told me frankly that he
was afraid that wouldn't have the time to go over these letters carefully
in the near future, whereupon, I suggested another plan.

On three occasions, relatives of survivors have uncovered in attic
or cellar, boxes of material which they did not personally have time to go
over. Mrs. Walter Reed allowed me to take with me all the remaining material
of her husband. So did Lazear's immediate relatives and so also did General
Jefferson R. Kean of Washington, who was Walter Reed's right-hand man in Cuba.
In each case I was allowed to have the material here at hand, to go over it
carefully at leisure and make such notes and copies as seemed historically
important. The material which the Lazear family loaned me contained hundreds
of personal letters between Mrs. Lazear and Doctor Lazear's mother, etc. etc.
Rest assured that all such personal data were respected and no copies were
made, the original letters being carefully returned to Mrs. Lazear. In each
instance, I first rearranged all the data in chronological sequence, then
read it carefully, laying aside only those which were of importance either in
giving an important date or illuminating the character of the writer, or be-
Dr. H. R. Carter, Jr.
- 2 -
February 7, 1948
cause of its medico-historical content. These latter letters were then care-
fully copied in sequence; after which I returned not only the original letters
to the owner, but in most cases was delighted to return typed copies of the
letters temporarily bound in sequence for the convenience of the family.

Now, Doctor Carter, I am most anxious to show to the full the im-
portance of your father's work in relation to the conquest of yellow fever.
I know of no other way to show you my earnestness in this matter. If you
have any question as to my purposes, I believe that Admiral Stitt would vouch
for me fully. General Walter L. Reed, the son of Walter Reed, I also know
quite well. Also Mrs. Blossom Reed, Walter Reed's daughter. Whatever help
you can give me in this matter I will most sincerely appreciate.

By separate post I am sending you a reprint which I think may interest
you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
